The original scheme of syllables might be replaced or enhanced with a rich repertoire of sounds, similar to Caucasian languages Ö cÊ¿. Over several millenia there must have been enormous creolic pressure to simplify the system phonetically. On the other hand, conflicting languages and merging consonant clusters might result in exotic sounds.  

â‰ˆ 2800 BC The sign inventory was reduced from some 1,500 signs to some 600 signs, and writing became increasingly phonological. [Determinant](Determinant.html) signs were re-introduced to avoid ambiguity. Use of the linear style as late as circa 2000 BC  

rotated 90Â° counterclockwise, in effect putting them on their side slightly before the Akkadian period, at the time of the Uruk ruler Lugalzagesi â‰ˆ 2270 BC  
when Sumerian stopped being a spoken language

There is deep logic embedded in cuneiform signs everywhere.  
It's almost like chinese mixing semantic and phonetic radicals :  

ğ’ related to limbs =>  
ğ’º GUB â‰ˆ ğ’† KAB, GAB2, GUB3 ğ’ + ğ’€¸ğ’¹  + ğ’‚  â‰ˆ ğ’‹— [left](left.html) [hand](hand.html) vs ğ“‚¾ leg
